indicators.justification:
The National System of Climate Change Metrics (SINAMECC), managed by the Dirección de Cambio Climático (DCC) of the Ministerio de Ambiente y Energía (MINAE) (1), groups data that are generated and compiled mainly by public entities on the subject. SINAMECC contains mitigation data on climate change. Specifically, there is data and information in the following categories: Plans and Policies, National Inventory of Greenhouse Gases and Carbon Absorption, Mitigation Actions, Carbon Neutrality Country Program, Sector Data, Sector Schemes, Climate Finance. Some of this data is fully disaggregated, but there are others that are at the aggregate level. They are data with a wide variety of download formats and but outdated, they also lack metadata that generate more information and context of the data sets.

## Sources:
(1): http://sinamecc.opendata.junar.com/home
(2): https://minae.go.cr/

evidence.title: SINAMECC
MINAE

indicators.justification:
The National Emergency Commission publishes a "threats map" that contains an inventory of natural threats in the territory. It includes local information on hydrometeorological, seismic, volcanic, landslides, and others types of natural disaster threats (1). It also has local information available. However, this information is general and it is not structured. 

##Sources: 
(1)https://www.cne.go.cr/reduccion_riesgo/mapas_amenzas/index.aspx

indicators.justification:
The Registry of Legal Persons of the National Registry offers information through internet consultations on the following topics:
1. Consultation of Documents for Presentation Appointments
2. Consultation of Legal Persons by Company Name
3. Consultation of Legal Persons by Legal Certificate
4. Consultation on the Tax on Legal Persons
5. Consult the Book of First Presentations
6. Consultation of Historical Movements of Companies
7. Consultation of the Natural Person Index.
8. Consult the Legal Person Index.

This information is not in database format, but is generated through web reports or documents issued by the National Registry, you must know very well what you are looking for in order to make the required queries.

In addition, the update periods are unknown, likewise they lack metadata that generate more information and context of the data.

## Sources:

(1): http://www.registronacional.go.cr/personas_juridicas/index.htm

indicators.justification:
Costa Rica has joined the international standard of open budget data (in English, Open Fiscal Data Package), promoted by the Global Initiative for Fiscal Transparency (GIFT, for its acronym in English, Global Initiative for Fiscal Transparency), in collaboration with the organization Open Knowledge International (OKI) and the BOOST Initiative of the World Bank.

 

On this site you can:

Download the Central Government Income Budget since 2015 according to the Public Sector Income Classifier.
Download the Budget of Expenditures and Execution of the Central Government, since 2015 according to the Classifiers of Expenditures of the Public Sector: Institutional, Economic, Functional, Object of Expenditure and by Source of Financing.
Have data sets in open format (CSV separated by commas) published under the CC BY-SA 4.0 license.
Access monthly updated data sets.
  

In addition, you can consult, download and use the information on the Income and Expenditure Budget of the Republic of Costa Rica

##Sources:
(1): https://www.hacienda.go.cr/contenido/15613-presupuesto-nacional-en-datos-abiertos
(2): https://www.fiscaltransparency.net/es/inicio/

evidence.title: Presupuesto Nacional de la República
Iniciativa Global para la Transparencia Fiscal (GIFT)

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

Currently the collection of these data is carried out manually and is provided by each political party. This system, in addition, would allow to have much more data than is available now.

indicators.justification:
The detailed structured data on the public procurement processes in Costa Rica are partially available as open data, since there is no central repository (1) with this information and, moreover, there are no open data for all stages, but for some basic elements such as the award.

## Sources:

(1): https://www.sicop.go.cr/index.jsp

Judiciary of Costa Rica (Open Contracting data standard)

The tender stage is covered.
The award stage is covered.
The contract implementation stage is covered.

indicators.justification:
In Costa Rica, the official Open Data initiative has been in force and formalized since 2016, counting from that moment on a team of at least 3 people who promote the initiative. Despite these budget and political prioritization restrictions, it has focused its efforts and impact from the National Open Data Commission, who have developed mechanisms such as the Guide to promote that institutions at the national level open data.

indicators.justification:
In general, the generation of open data initiatives in local governments has been extremely limited and depends on human and budgetary capacities within the municipalities. Most of them have been within the Greater Metropolitan Area, that is, there is a gap with the local governments of the regions. Likewise, the municipalities that have advanced have focused only on openness and not on the use and impact of open data.

indicators.justification:
The Law No. 7600 on Equal Opportunities for Persons with Disabilities (1), that aims to: a) Serve as an instrument for people with disabilities to achieve their maximum development, their full social participation, as well as the exercise of the rights and duties established in our legal system. b) Guarantee equal opportunities for the Costa Rican population in areas such as: health, education, work, family life, recreation, sports, culture and all other established areas. c) Eliminate any type of discrimination against people with disabilities. d) Establish the legal and material bases that allow Costa Rican society to adopt the necessary measures for equalization of opportunities and non-discrimination of people with disabilities. Chapter VI covers the issues on access to information.

Also, there is the article 9 of the National Code of Digital Technologies on accessibility issues (2).

Besides these two frameworks, accessibility on data has not been further covered. This element has not been the responsibility of any institutional instance or work team. Therefore, there is nothing to say about quality issues.

indicators.justification:
In 2011, the Legislative Assembly approved the Law for the Protection of the Person against the processing of their personal data, and its regulations. The latter was the subject of a reform in 2016 to specify the scope of the standard in aspects that initially raised doubts.

Now Law 8968 falls short, due to the changes that have been witnessed since its approval, and current law initiatives in the world refer to instruments such as the General Data Protection Regulation of the European Union.

In addition, in the country the discussion around the protection of personal data has gained relevance. The foregoing by the questioned Presidential Data Analysis Unit (UPAD), whose function was to use data intelligence for public policy, including through access to confidential information. The decree was repealed after the wave of criticism and the investigation is ongoing.

In 2021, (2) deputies of the ruling party presented the legislative initiative Comprehensive Reform of the Law for the Protection of the Person Against the Treatment of Personal Data.

indicators.justification:
Although Costa Rica does not have specific regulations, laws, regulations, policies and guidelines that require that the data collection and publication processes be available in the official or national languages of the country, the Political Constitution declares Spanish as the official language, and promotes indigenous languages (1). Also, there are some isolated efforts by public bodies (INEC, Archivo, and MICITT (2)) to generate some guidelines on compilation, interoperability, and publication.

indicators.justification:
In October 2016, under the leadership of the Vice Ministry of the Presidency for Political Affairs and Citizen Dialogue, the country adopted the principles of the International Open Data Charter, which were a reference for decree 40199-Opening of Public Data (1) , signed in May 2017 and where it is established as the National Policy for the Opening of Public Data (PNADP)

The PNADP creates the Technical Secretariat for the Opening of Public Data in the Ministry of Communication, which will be the executing agency of the policy, based on the recommendations of the National Open Data Commission (CNDA) (2), as well as the entity coordinator of the institutional open data teams (established in the decrees). It also stands out that the only resources that this policy has is human talent, since an annual budget has not been established for this instance.

Despite the fact that the law promotes the transparency of budget information, there is no reference in the regulations on the opening of data in this matter. Despite this, there are efforts to make this information published in an open format, for example what was promoted in decree 40199. It is required that the subject of open data be established in budgetary regulations so that the management of this kind of information is more open and transparent.

indicators.justification:
In Costa Rica, the information related to the income, budgeting, custody, supervision, administration, investment and expenditure of public funds, as well as the information necessary to ensure the effectiveness of the Law Against Corruption and Illicit Enrichment in the Public Function, is of public interest.

However, the Office of the Comptroller General of the Republic may only review private documents in accordance with the provisions of Article 24 of the Political Constitution and Article 11 of the Law Against Corruption and Illicit Enrichment in the Public Function.

Therefore, there is a legal restriction to be able to have this data in open formats.

indicators.justification:
On the one hand, the Ministry of Finance, which is the entity responsible for managing the Integrated System of Public Procurement of the State (SICOP), must make the necessary modifications so that this is a platform adapted to the logic of open contracting, capable of publishing information in accordance with the demands of citizens, focused on transparency and accountability, and not just an electronic page to manage contracts.

SICOP should improve the publication of data on the execution phase of contracts. The publication of the opening stage, receipt of offers and award is relatively comprehensive, but in the execution stage there are still gaps. In addition, it should aim for the information to be available in a structured format under the Data Standard for Open Contracts, as the Judiciary has begun to do, for greater ease of analysis and monitoring. But (1) Smart Tenders analyzes, on a daily basis, public purchases and summarizes the most important data for companies to focus on offers to the State.
